stems: put (someone or something) to the test

text: {bc}a set of questions or problems that are designed to measure a person's knowledge, skills, or abilities
{dx}see also {dxt|intelligence test||} {dxt|rorschach test||} {dxt|screen test||}{/dx}

examples.text: She is studying for her math/spelling/history {it}test{/it}.
I passed/failed/flunked my biology {it}test{/it}.
The teacher sat at his desk grading {it}tests{/it}.
a driver's/driving {it}test{/it} [=a test that is used to see if someone is able to safely drive a car]
an IQ {it}test{/it}
{it}test{/it} questions
The {it}test{/it} will be on [=the questions on the test will be about] the first three chapters of the book.
We {phrase}took/had a test{/phrase} on European capitals. = ({it}Brit{/it}) We {phrase}did a test{/phrase} on European capitals.
The college relies on {phrase}test scores{/phrase} in its admissions process.

text: {bc}a careful study of a part of the body or of a substance taken from the body
{dx}see also {dxt|blood test||} {dxt|breath test||} {dxt|stress test||}{/dx}

examples.text: The {it}test{/it} showed/revealed a problem with your liver function.
a vision/hearing {it}test{/it} [=a test that shows how well you see/hear]
a urine {it}test{/it} [=a test that examines a person's urine for evidence of disease or illegal drugs]
allergy {it}tests{/it} [=tests that show what you are allergic to]
All applicants must pass a {phrase}drug test{/phrase}. [=a test that examines a person's blood or urine for evidence of illegal drugs]
The doctor will call you with the {phrase}test results{/phrase}.
They went to the drug store to buy a {phrase}pregnancy test{/phrase}. [=a device that reacts to a woman's urine in a way that shows whether or not she is pregnant]
a {phrase}DNA test{/phrase} [=a test that examines DNA and that is used to identify someone or to show that people are relatives]

text: {bc}a careful study of a small amount of water, soil, air, etc., in order to see if its quality is good, to find out if it contains a dangerous substance, etc.

examples.text: The {it}test{/it} indicated high levels of lead in the soil.
routine water {it}tests{/it}

text: {bc}a planned and usually controlled act or series of acts that is done to learn something, to see if something works properly, etc.
{dx}see also {dxt|road test||}{/dx}

examples.text: lab/laboratory {it}tests{/it}
underground nuclear {it}tests{/it}
a {it}test{/it} of a new vaccine
{phrase}Taste tests{/phrase} revealed that people prefer this brand of cola over that one.

text: {bc}something (such as a difficult situation or task) that shows how strong or skilled someone or something is
{dx}see also {dxt|acid test||} {dxt|litmus test||}{/dx}

examples.text: a {it}test{/it} of will/strength/character
The real/true {it}test{/it} of your ability as a skier is whether you can ski well on very hard snow.

text: {bc}{sx|test match||}

definedRunOns.definedRunOnPhrase: put (someone or something) to the test

text: {bc}to cause (someone or something) to be in a situation that shows how strong, good, etc., that person or thing really is

examples.text: The team has been playing well so far, but tomorrow's game will really {it}put them to the test{/it}. [=will really test them]
A trip through the desert will {it}put{/it} the truck {it}to the test{/it}.
We decided to {it}put{/it} the idea/theory {it}to the test{/it} [=to test the theory] with a little experiment.

text: {bc}to continue to be important, respected, etc., for a long period of time

examples.text: Great art/literature/music can {it}stand the test of time{/it}.

text: {dx}see {dxt|character||}{/dx}

shortDefinitions: a set of questions or problems that are designed to measure a person's knowledge, skills, or abilities
a careful study of a part of the body or of a substance taken from the body
a careful study of a small amount of water, soil, air, etc., in order to see if its quality is good, to find out if it contains a dangerous substance, etc.

text: {bc}to use a set of questions or problems to measure someone's skills, knowledge, or abilities

examples.text: Weekly quizzes will {it}test{/it} your understanding of the material.
The students will all be {it}tested{/it} again at the end of the school year.

text: {bc}to examine a part of the body or a substance taken from the body

examples.text: The school nurse will be {it}testing{/it} students' hearing next week.
The athletes knew that tournament officials would be {it}testing for{/it} (the presence of) illegal drugs.
She {phrase}tested positive/negative{/phrase} {it}for{/it} AIDS.

text: {bc}to examine a small amount of water, soil, air, etc., in order to see if its quality is good, if it contains a dangerous substance, etc.

examples.text: The water gets {it}tested{/it} regularly.

text: {bc}to use (something) in a planned and usually controlled way in order to see if it works properly
{dx}see also {dxt|field-test||}{/dx}

examples.text: Only one of the vehicles they {it}tested{/it} performed well in wet conditions.
Researchers are currently {it}testing{/it} (the safety of) the vaccine.
The vaccine has not been {it}tested{/it} on humans yet.
We designed a series of experiments to {it}test{/it} our hypothesis.

text: {bc}to show how strong, good, etc., someone or something is in a difficult situation
{dx}see also {dxt|time-tested||}{/dx}

examples.text: The stress is {it}testing{/it} the strength of our relationship.
The scandal is {it}testing{/it} the country's faith in its leadership.
Life's ordeals {it}test{/it} us.
You're {it}testing{/it} my patience. [=you are starting to make me annoyed or upset]

text: {bc}to do something to find out if people like or approve a possible plan, product, etc., so that you can make a decision about it

examples.text: The company is {it}testing the waters{/it} with a new online version of the product.
She's {it}testing the waters{/it} for a presidential bid.

shortDefinitions: to use a set of questions or problems to measure someone's skills, knowledge, or abilities —often + on
to examine a part of the body or a substance taken from the body —often + for
to examine a small amount of water, soil, air, etc., in order to see if its quality is good, if it contains a dangerous substance, etc. —often + for —+ for

text: {bc}an official agreement between countries with nuclear weapons to not test those weapons

examples.text: a nuclear {it}test ban{/it} treaty

shortDefinitions: an official agreement between countries with nuclear weapons to not test those weapons

text: {bc}a legal case that will be used as an example when other similar cases are decided in the future

shortDefinitions: a legal case that will be used as an example when other similar cases are decided in the future

text: {bc}an occurrence in which you drive a car that you do not own to see if you like it and would like to buy it

examples.text: Would you like to take the car for a {it}test drive{/it}?

shortDefinitions: an occurrence in which you drive a car that you do not own to see if you like it and would like to buy it

text: {bc}a game or series of games of cricket or rugby played by teams from different countries

shortDefinitions: a game or series of games of cricket or rugby played by teams from different countries

text: {bc}a pilot who flies new aircraft in order to see how well they work

shortDefinitions: a pilot who flies new aircraft in order to see how well they work

text: {bc}an occurrence in which a product or procedure is tried in order to see if it works correctly {bc}{sx|trial run||}

examples.text: They did a {it}test run{/it} of the new software.

shortDefinitions: an occurrence in which a product or procedure is tried in order to see if it works correctly : trial run

text: {bc}a glass container that is shaped like a tube which is closed at one end and that is used especially in science experiments

shortDefinitions: a glass container that is shaped like a tube which is closed at one end and that is used especially in science experiments

text: {bc}a child produced from an egg that was fertilized outside of a woman's body and then put back into the woman's body to finish developing

shortDefinitions: a child produced from an egg that was fertilized outside of a woman's body and then put back into the woman's body to finish developing
